DOCNAME: CASE OF JOANNA SZULC v. POLAND
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 8 - Right to respect for private and family life (Article 8 - Positive obligations;Article 8-1 - Respect for private life);Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . According to the applicant , in DATE she received a job offer from the NORP company ORG which she apparently refused . In DATE she worked for ORG in GPE and in DATE for ORG .

CARDINAL . On a few occasions the security services attempted to recruit her as a collaborator but the applicant never consented despite threats . In DATE the applicant was summoned to ORG . She had a conversation with an officer of the counterintelligence service in connection with the job offer from the NORP company . The officer tried to persuade her to collaborate with the service but the applicant refused and stated that she would rather decline the job offer .

CARDINAL . NORP Subsequent meetings with officers of ORG ( NORP ORG ) took place in DATE . The applicant consistently refused to collaborate . CARDINAL such meeting took place in connection with the applicant ’s request to obtain a passport for a holiday trip to GPE . The applicant was instructed to prepare a report from her trip which she submitted upon her return .
CARDINAL . For DATE the applicant lived in GPE . She was involved in the activities supporting the ORG ( “ GPE ) ORG in GPE .

CARDINAL . The PERSON of DATE on ORG ( “ the Institute Act ” ; PERSON o Instytucie Pamięci Narodowej – Komisji Ścigania GPE przeciwko FAC ) entered into force on DATE . ORG tasks included , inter alia , storing and researching documents of the communist security services . The right of access to those documents was guaranteed primarily to “ injured parties ” as defined in LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to ORG ( “ the Institute ” ) for leave to consult all documents collected on her by the security services .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the applicant received a certificate informing her that she could not be considered an “ injured party ” ( pokrzywdzona ) within the meaning of section CARDINAL of the Institute Act . In a letter of the same date she was informed that the ORG would continue to search the archives for documents regarding her . The certificate which the applicant received simply indicated that after CARDINAL rounds of search the ORG had not found any documents created by the former security services about her .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG reviewed the constitutionality of the provisions of LAW regarding access to documents held by ORG ( case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . It found , inter alia , that sections CARDINAL § CARDINAL and QUANTITY of LAW , in so far as they deprived interested persons DATE other than injured parties – of the right to be provided with information about documents concerning them , were unconstitutional ( see Relevant domestic law below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again applied for access to all documents collected on her by the security services . She relied on the above ORG judgment of DATE . According to the applicant , that judgment stipulated that every interested person had the right to have access to documents held by the ORG concerning him or her on the basis of LAW , regardless of whether he or she had been granted the status of the “ injured party ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was allowed to consult documents in her file which concerned her as a subject of interest of the former security services ( obiekt zainteresowania ORG ) . However , she did not receive access to all documents about her and she could not receive any copies or make notes .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again applied to the President of ORG leave to consult all documents concerning her . She noted that the documents which she was allowed to consult so far confirmed that she had refused to collaborate with the security services . The applicant learnt for the first time from those documents that the security services had invented a plan to subject her to surveillance . She also discovered that she had been given a code name and expressed her indignation in this respect .

CARDINAL . In reply , on DATE , the Deputy Head of ORG informed the applicant that her request to have access to all documents concerning her could not be granted . In his view , according to ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE the right of access to documents did not extend to all documents concerning the applicant but was applicable exclusively to those which treated her as a subject of interest of the former security services . Accordingly , she was informed that the consultation of documents by the applicant which had taken place on DATE had been carried out in accordance with the procedure adopted by the ORG and that all documents which treated her as a subject had been disclosed .

CARDINAL . LAW was amended by the Law of DATE on disclosing information about the documents of the ORG security services from DATE and the content of these documents ( “ the CARDINAL LAW ” ) , which entered into force on DATE . Henceforth , the rules on access to documents deposited with the ORG were set out in amended sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( see Relevant domestic law below ) . The status of an “ injured party ” was repealed . The amended LAW further stipulated that the ORG will create an Internet catalogue of persons who had collaborated or assisted the former ORG security services in their undercover activities .
CARDINAL . LAW and the CARDINAL LAW were further amended by the PERSON of DATE which entered into force on DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant , having been aware that her name appeared on the “ GPE list ” ( see part C. below ) , was concerned that her name might be included in the official catalogue . This would have amounted to her official condemnation as an informant of the communist security services only on the basis of the entries made by the officers of those services without the applicant ’s having been aware of it .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) found LAW and LAW as amended to a large extent unconstitutional and quashed many of its provisions with effect from DATE . It struck down , among others , section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW which excluded access of interested persons to documents indicating that they had collaborated or assisted the former ORG security services in their undercover activities ( see Relevant domestic law below ) .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the applicant had again requested access to all documents concerning her pursuant to the rules in force as from DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Director of ORG of the ORG gave a decision in which it refused her access to CARDINAL documents . He considered that the content of these CARDINAL documents fulfilled the conditions specified in section QUANTITY ) of LAW . This provision stipulated that the refusal to allow access to documents whose content indicated that the petitioner had been considered by the security services as a secret informant or an assistant in covert gathering of information should be given in the form of an administrative decision .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against that decision , submitting that it had been given pursuant to the rules declared unconstitutional by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of the ORG quashed the decision on procedural grounds and referred the case back . He found that the Director of ORG of the Institute had not ruled on the application of ORG , a human rights organisation , to join the proceedings as a third party .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Director of the GPE Branch of the ORG gave a decision in which it refused the applicant access to CARDINAL documents . He again relied on section QUANTITY ) of LAW . The applicant appealed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of the ORG upheld the impugned decision . He confirmed that the documents at issue indicated that the applicant had been considered by the security services as a secret informant or an assistant in the covert gathering of information . Accordingly , the refusal of access was justified under section DATE ) of LAW .

With regard to the applicant ’s argument that the decision was based on the unconstitutional norm , the President of the ORG noted that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW constituted a substantive legal basis for granting or refusing access to documents , while section QUANTITY was a procedural provision . However , since the legislator decided to replicate in LAW the same conditions justifying refusal as stipulated in CARDINAL LAW then the former provision could not be interpreted without taking into account these conditions . The President of the ORG did not accept the applicant ’s argument that since section CARDINAL § CARDINAL had been declared unconstitutional and repealed , then it followed that a different provision ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) with the same content was also unconstitutional . He went on to say that only when ORG expressly declared unconstitutional a given provision of the law was the authority under the obligation not to apply such provision .
CARDINAL . The applicant lodged a complaint against the decision with ORG . On DATE ORG dismissed her complaint .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a cassation appeal with ORG . She argued , inter alia , that the decisions of the ORG refusing her access to documents of the security services entailed a breach of a number of constitutional provisions and of LAW . They were , furthermore contrary to ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG stayed the proceedings on the ground that a legal question on the constitutionality of , inter alia , section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW had been put to ORG by a different panel of ORG . This provision was relied on as the basis of the ORG ’s negative decisions in the applicant ’s case .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( case no . P CARDINAL ) ruled , among others , that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW was incompatible with the LAW , in particular the right to protection of private life ( LAW ) , the right of access to official documents concerning oneself ( LAW ) and the right to request the correction or deletion of untrue or incomplete information ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG resumed the proceedings . On DATE it gave judgment quashing ORG judgment and the CARDINAL preceding decisions of the ORG . It relied on ORG judgment of DATE , in particular that court ’s finding of unconstitutionality of section QUANTITY which had served as the legal basis of the decisions in the applicant ’s case .
CARDINAL . On DATE at the GPE Branch of ORG the applicant was granted access to copies of all documents concerning her which had been created by the communist security services .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG decided to create a list of officers , collaborators , candidates for collaborators of the ORG security services and of other persons whose files had been collected by it . This list consisted of the first name , the surname and , in some cases , the case file number . The list was made available on computers in the ORG library , to which access was restricted to researchers and journalists .

CARDINAL . In DATE the list , consisting of CARDINAL names , was published on the Internet and unofficially named “ the GPE list ” ( “ PERSON GPE ” ) after a journalist who had allegedly removed it from ORG and published it . The publication of the list received wide media coverage , particularly since the names of some important public figures appeared on it .

CARDINAL . In response to these events , on DATE ORG passed an amendment to LAW and added section CARDINALa , which afforded persons concerned the right to obtain a certificate clarifying whether their name was on the list .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant discovered that her name appeared on the “ GPE list ” . On DATE she applied to the Institute for clarification of whether her personal details corresponded to the data on the “ ORG list ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG issued a certificate confirming that her personal details ( names , surname , date and place of birth ) corresponded to the data included in the GPE ’s catalogue of officers , collaborators , candidates for collaborators of the ORG security services and of other persons . At the same time she was informed that the certificate did not confer on her the status of an “ injured party ” and did not entitle her to access documents held by the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested ORG to institute the so - called “ auto – lustration ” proceedings under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the CARDINAL LAW . This provision stipulated that lustration proceedings could also be instituted by a person who prior to the entry into force of LAW had held a public office and who was publicly accused of having been working or collaborating with the ORG security services DATE . The applicant relied on ORG judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , which extended the application of that provision to persons who had not held public office . She submitted her lustration declaration , in which she denied having been an intentional and secret collaborator with the secret services and requested the court to give a ruling that her declaration was true . The applicant maintained that the fact that her name had appeared on the “ GPE list ” , which had been made public on the Internet , constituted public accusation since the list had been regarded by the general public as a list of agents and collaborators .

CARDINAL . She submitted that ORG had refused to grant her the status of an injured party and subsequently had denied her access to certain documents concerning her . These circumstances could have indicated that there had been some documents showing that she had collaborated with the security services . Additionally , she found her name on the “ GPE list ” and received a certificate that her personal data matched those on the said list . The applicant argued that such situation was grossly unfair and demanded to institute lustration proceedings with a view to terminating any speculation about her alleged collaboration with the security services . She also hoped that in the framework of these proceedings she would be provided with access to all documents about her stored by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed her application to institute lustration proceedings , considering that she had not been publicly accused of having been a secret collaborator within the meaning of Article CARDINAL ) of the CARDINAL Lustration Act . Firstly , it was not certain that she was the person whose name had been on the list . Even assuming that her name had been on the list , such fact could not be tantamount to an accusation of having collaborated with the security services . The court noted that the media had reported that the list had been only a sort of a catalogue facilitating the use of ORG archives . It contained the names of persons who had been registered by the security services for various reasons ; some had been actual secret collaborators but there were other persons who had been preselected for that role , without necessarily having been aware of that fact .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the impugned decision . The court found that there were no sufficient grounds to consider that the applicant had been publicly accused of having collaborated with the security services . The list of names produced by the applicant indicated that it contained not only the names of agents but also of victims . Furthermore , the court found that the applicant had not established that the inclusion of her name on the list had had any specific adverse consequences for her . It considered relevant that the ORG ’s decisions and certificates referred to by the applicant were not public documents . No further appeal lay against that judgment .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the LAW of DATE provides :
“ Everyone shall have the right to legal protection of his private and family life , of his honour and good reputation and to make decisions about his personal life . ”
CARDINAL . Article QUANTITY :
“ CARDINAL . Everyone shall have the right of access to official documents and data collections concerning himself . Limitations upon such rights may be established by statute .
CARDINAL . Everyone shall have the right to demand the correction or deletion of untrue or incomplete information , or information acquired by means contrary to statute . ”

CARDINAL . The PERSON of DATE on ORG ( “ the Institute Act ” ; PERSON o Instytucie Pamięci Narodowej – Komisji Ścigania GPE przeciwko FAC ) entered into force on DATE . ORG tasks included , inter alia , storing and researching documents of the communist security services . The right of access to those documents was guaranteed primarily to “ injured parties ” as defined in LAW . Limited access was further provided to officers , employees and collaborators of the security services and separately to researchers and journalists .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provided that an “ injured party ” ( pokrzywdzony ) was a person on whom the ORG security services deliberately collected information , including secretly . However , a person who subsequently became an officer , employee or a collaborator of the security services could not be considered an “ injured party ” ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

According to section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW everyone had the right to inquire whether he or she was an injured party within the meaning of the LAW . Person certified as an “ injured party ” had the right to obtain information from the ORG about documents concerning him ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . ORG had the obligation to inform the “ injured party ” about the manner of access to the documents concerning him and to provide him , on request , copies of those documents ( section QUANTITY ) . LAW further provided that an “ injured party ” had the right to submit his or her corrections to and clarifications in respect of existing documents .

CARDINAL . On DATE a group of deputies to the PERSON introduced a bill amending LAW . They noted that the ORG ’s catalogue of officers , secret collaborators and candidates for secret collaborators did not include any other details than a name and the surname of those persons . This situation led to a general uncertainty and created suspicions in respect of many persons who had not had in the past any contacts with the ORG security services . Their bill was intended to remedy the situation .
DATE . On DATE ORG passed the amendment to LAW . On DATE new section CARDINALa ( CARDINAL ) of the IPN Act came into force . It provided as follows :

“ The President of ORG shall within DATE of an application issue a certificate stating whether or not the personal details of the applicant correspond to the personal details included in the list of officers , collaborators and proposed collaborators of the ORG security services ... or other persons that was made accessible at the ORG as of DATE . ”
CARDINAL . In DATE the ORG challenged the constitutionality of certain provisions of LAW concerning access to documents held by ORG .

On DATE the ORG gave judgment in case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL . It held , inter alia , that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL and section QUANTITY and CARDINAL taken in conjunction with section QUANTITY of LAW , in so far as they deprived interested persons DATE other than injured parties – of the right to be provided with information about documents concerning them , were incompatible with LAW ( protection of private life ) and LAW and CARDINAL ( the right of access to official documents concerning oneself and the right to demand the correction or deletion of untrue or incomplete information ) of LAW . It further found that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL taken in conjunction with section QUANTITY of LAW , in so far as it deprived interested persons DATE other than injured parties – of the right to submit their corrections to and clarifications in respect of documents concerning them , was incompatible with the same constitutional provisions .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that LAW justifiably afforded special status to the “ injured party ” and bestowed on this category of persons a number of rights . It identified under LAW a distinct category of persons , namely those who applied for the status of the “ injured party ” and whose applications were refused . The refusal resulted either from the lack of documents concerning a person seeking the status or from the fact that the security services had not collected information on them . The Constitutional Court disagreed with the ORG that the ORG ’s refusal to classify a person as the “ injured party ” had been tantamount to an official declaration that such person had been an officer , employee or collaborator of the ORG security services . At the same time it pointed to the incoherent criteria used by ORG in classifying persons as collaborators of the security services . It also noted that ORG archives contained information which had been , in principle , collected without any legal basis and often unlawfully . ORG underlined that the constitutional right of access to official documents ( LAW ) was related solely to the documents concerning a given person as a subject of interest of the security services . It did not extend to documents which were created by a given person in his capacity of an officer , employee or collaborator of the security services .

CARDINAL . LAW was amended by the Law of DATE on disclosing information about the documents of the ORG security services from DATE and the content of these documents ( “ the CARDINAL LAW ” ; ustawa o ujawnianiu informacji o dokumentach organów bezpieczeństwa państwa z lat QUANTITY treści tych dokumentów ) . The amendments entered into force on DATE .
CARDINAL . The DATE LAW and LAW were further amended by LAW DATE . These amendments entered into force on DATE .
CARDINAL . The amended sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL regarding access to documents held by the ORG stated in so far as relevant :
“ LAW . CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to request ORG for access to copies of documents concerning him .
CARDINAL . The ORG grants access to copies of available documents concerning the applicant , which are referred to in DATE , with the exception of the following :

CARDINAL ) documents created by the applicant or with his participation ... in connection with his employment or service in the ORG security agencies or in connection with his activities carried out as a secret informant or an assistant in covert gathering of information ;
CARDINAL ) documents whose content indicates that the applicant :
a ) was considered by the security services as a secret informant or an assistant in covert gathering of information ,
b ) undertook to provide information to the ORG security service or to assist such service in whatever form in its covert activities ,
c ) executed tasks given by the ORG security service , in particular provided information to the service . ...
Section CARDINAL . CARDINAL . A refusal to allow request , referred to in DATE , in so far as it concerned access to documents :

CARDINAL ) created by the applicant or with his participation ... in connection with his employment or service in the ORG security agencies or in connection with his activities carried out as a secret informant or an assistant in covert gathering of information ;
CARDINAL ) whose content indicates that the applicant :
a ) was considered by the security services as a secret informant or an assistant in covert gathering of information ,
b ) undertook to provide information to the ORG security service or to assist such service in whatever form in its covert activities ,
c ) executed tasks given by the ORG security service , in particular provided information to the service ,
is effected in the form of an administrative decision . ... ”

CARDINAL . In the case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ORG reviewed the constitutionality of the CARDINAL Lustration Act and LAW as amended which had been challenged by a group of members of parliament . It gave its seminal judgment on the issues of lustration and access to documents held by ORG .

CARDINAL . With regard to the issue of access to documents , ORG struck down as unconstitutional section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW . This provision excluded access of interested persons to documents indicating that that they had collaborated or assisted the former ORG security services in their undercover activities . ORG noted that the LAW guaranteed to everyone the right of access to official documents and data collections concerning oneself ( LAW ) and the right to demand the correction or deletion of untrue or incomplete information , or information acquired by unlawful means ( LAW ) . This latter right , which was related to the right to privacy guaranteed in LAW , could not be statutorily restricted to a certain category of persons . ORG underlined that no ORG interest could legitimise or justify preservation in official records of information which was untrue , incomplete or acquired in a manner contrary to statute .

CARDINAL . It further declared unconstitutional section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) of LAW . The latter provision stipulated that ORG was charged with preparation and publication of catalogues of persons referred to in LAW ) . The wording used in this provision was identical to the formulation employed in LAW .

ORG noted that such catalogues would rely on classification adopted by the totalitarian security services and their assessment of a person . In its view , the publication of such catalogues would have amounted to legitimisation of the activities of the security services and , at the same time , to stigmatisation of persons included in these catalogues . Such a situation would be incompatible with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the LAW .
CARDINAL . The judgment was promulgated on CARDINAL DATE and on DATE the unconstitutional provisions were abrogated .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Speaker of the PERSON requested ORG for interpretation of the judgment of CARDINAL DATE . He submitted , inter alia , that the court had not given reasons for its finding of unconstitutionality in respect of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that there was no doubt that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) had been declared unconstitutional . It observed that the Speaker ’s request was aimed at supplementing the reasons for the judgment ; however there was no such possibility under LAW . Nonetheless , ORG drew attention to the fact that the sections CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) of LAW , which both had been declared unconstitutional , had identical content and thus they had concerned the same legal norm although spelled out in CARDINAL different provisions . Both provisions concerned the same group of persons , namely those considered by the ORG security services as a secret informants or assistants in covert gathering of information . ORG noted that the reasons for the finding of unconstitutionality in respect of section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) were equally applicable to section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW . It noted that an unconstitutional legal norm could appear in part as well as in one or more legal provisions ; however the finding of unconstitutionality of a legal norm and hence its disqualification was relevant for all situations in which such norm may be applied .
CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court further held as follows :

“ It should be underlined that the same category of persons [ as mentioned in LAW ) ] is referred to in LAW ) of LAW which was not challenged in the case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL and thus was not reviewed by ORG . However , the lack of review in this part [ in respect of this provision ] can not justify negative administrative decisions issued on the basis of CARDINAL of LAW only for the reason that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) survived as a result of the lack of challenge to it . LAW is functionally connected with the content of section DATE ) and may produce legal consequences only in so far as it is harmonised with the content of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) following the intervention of ORG in respect of the latter , as well as in respect of section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) of LAW . What is decisive in such situations is the fact that a legal norm ( included in section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) of LAW , and used also in unchallenged section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) was declared unconstitutional in the judgment of ORG . It is also relevant that section CARDINAL of LAW determines solely a form of the decision refusing request for access to copies of documents concerning [ an applicant ] , while the immediately preceding it section CARDINAL speaks of the individual right of access to documents , which is an implementation at the statutory level of the constitutional principle of access of every person to official documents and data collections specified in LAW . It is obvious that the provision regulating solely a form of a decision in respect of a given right , in this case an administrative decision , may not serve as the basis for determination of the substantive content of the right , its scope and the conditions for its realisation . ”
CARDINAL . In DATE ORG and ORG put to the ORG legal questions on the constitutionality of various provisions of LAW , including LAW ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Constitutional Court gave judgment . It held that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , in its version applicable up until DATE , was incompatible , among others , with Articles CARDINAL and QUANTITY of the LAW in conjunction with LAW of LAW ( the principle of proportionality ) .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court widely referred to its decision of CARDINAL DATE ( see above ) and confirmed that a finding of unconstitutionality in respect of a given legal norm was authoritative for all situations in which such norm may be applied , regardless of whether the norm was included in CARDINAL or more legal provisions .
ORG also relied on its findings in the judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . It summarised its approach in that case as follows :

“ ... for institutional , functional and procedural reasons LAW together with LAW constitute CARDINAL instrument . In this connection , if the documents created and collected by the ORG security services , meant to indicate the collaboration within the meaning of section QUANTITY of the CARDINAL LAW , are constituting the basis for drawing adverse social , moral , political as well as legal consequences in respect of persons subjected to lustration and other persons whose data were registered and included in catalogues [ of the ORG ] , [ then ] such persons , in a democratic ORG ruled by law , have to have the right to defend their dignity , reputation and good name . Accordingly , they have to be accorded the right of access to the full range of documents concerning them and used against them . ... This right has to encompass access to documents , deposited with the ORG , in which interested persons were attributed an involvement in the creation of these documents . This is relevant from the point of view of the content of those documents , conclusions formulated and drawn by the officers of the ORG security services on the basis of the transmitted information and , in particular , from the point of view of the supposed intention of a person passing on the information to “ violate the rights and freedoms of a man and a citizen ” ”

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court observed that section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW was of procedural character , but it further specified the grounds for a decision refusing access to certain documents . These conditions matched the content of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW which had been abrogated as a result of the finding of its unconstitutionality . Nonetheless , the administrative courts submitted to ORG that in practice section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) had been used by the ORG as a substantive basis for decisions refusing access to documents specified in this provision . It further noted that after the said judgment the parliament amended LAW on CARDINAL occasions ; however it did not amend section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court found that a limitation on access to documents of persons , which were referred to in the unconstitutional section CARDINAL § CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , which was imposed in a procedural rather than substantive form in section QUANTITY ) , amounted to unjustified interference with the informational autonomy of an individual and restricted the constitutional right to request the correction or deletion of untrue or incomplete information ( LAW ) . ORG held that that limitations specified in LAW ) of LAW on access of interested persons to official documents concerning them were constitutionally disproportionate , and thus in breach of NORP CARDINAL and QUANTITY of the LAW in conjunction with LAW of LAW . It further held that the impugned provision was incompatible with LAW ( the rule of law principle ) on account of the excessive degree of its imprecision and vagueness .

CARDINAL . On DATE the parliament passed amendments to LAW which entered into force on DATE . According to the new wording of CARDINAL of LAW everyone had the right of access to documents concerning him which were deposited with the Institute . The limitations on access which were examined by ORG in its judgment of DATE were repealed .
